title: Tinnitus Following Concussion
chief_complaint: I have a ringing in my left ear that started suddenly after my car accident. It's very disturbing during the day, and I'm also dealing with sensitivity to sounds.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 7 months prior following a motor-vehicle accident (rear-ended, whiplash, occipital lobe impact).
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear tinnitus; bilateral sound sensitivity.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Vision loss, imbalance, sound sensitivity, sleep disturbance, central tremor, anxiety.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe handicap (THI 68) and functional index (TFI 76). High anxiety related to symptoms.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated to find the precise pitch of tinnitus; seeking diagnosis and treatment options.

history.present_illness: Patient seen 7 months post-MVA. Post Concussion Symptom Scale score of 77. Reports tinnitus specifically in the left ear. Most disturbance during the day. Sleep disturbance attributed to anxiety rather than tinnitus directly.
history.otologic_history: No previous history of otologic disorders or surgery.
history.medical_psych_history: Beck Depression Screening score of 7 (normal). High anxiety observed during testing.
history.prior_management: Seen by neurology; medication list did not include known sources of tinnitus.
history.patient_goals: Adamant about knowing the precise tinnitus pitch; requested booth door ajar during testing.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. Right ear is normal through 6000 Hz with mild-to-moderate loss at 8000 Hz+. Left ear shows mild-to-moderate SNHL beginning at 3000 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_Ear_Thresholds: Normal <20 dB HL up to 6 kHz; dip to ~30-40 dB HL at high frequencies.
numeric_results.Left_Ear_Thresholds: Normal <20 dB HL up to 2 kHz; drops to ~35 dB HL at 3-4 kHz, ~50 dB HL at 6 kHz, ~60 dB HL at 8 kHz.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Jerger Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Not conducted/Aborted. Uncomfortable loudness (UCL) levels were reached at 80-90 dB HL. Testing at 80 dB was attempted but aborted due to reported discomfort.

tests.name: Distortion Product Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.key_findings: Present at 6-dB SNR. Normal amplitudes for 8/13 frequencies in the Right ear vs 4/13 frequencies in the Left ear, consistent with the asymmetric hearing loss.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: Pitch matched to high frequency (~9 kHz). High Minimum Masking Level (MML) in the left ear. Positive residual inhibition (3 seconds). Patient became upset during testing, worried about 'performance'.

tests.name: Self-Directed Tinnitus Match (Levo)
tests.key_findings: Patient performed self-match to feel more confident. Took 15 minutes and 4 trials.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (Left worse than Right) and normal middle ear function. There is significant sound tolerance checking (hyperacusis) preventing suprathreshold reflex testing. Tinnitus is high-pitched (~9 kHz) with severe functional impact and high anxiety levels.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows some high-frequency hearing loss, which is likely contributing to the tinnitus.
The testing we did today is an approximation to help us guide treatment; it is okay if you didn't find the 'perfect' pitch match immediately.
The anxiety you are feeling is understandable given the accident, and treating the hearing loss and tinnitus can help reduce that burden.
Because of the hearing loss and tinnitus, amplification (hearing aids) combined with sound therapy is a strong option to consider.
notes_for_actor: Portray high anxiety and emotional fragility. You are very worried about 'failing' the test.
Be adamant about finding the *exact* pitch of your tinnitus. Ask the audiologist repeatedly if they are sure about the results.
Express discomfort with loud sounds (hyperacusis) if the audiologist suggests loud testing.
Request the booth door be left ajar due to anxiety/claustrophobia.
